data.title: House Film Unit at Warner Bros.
data.meta_description: Warner Brothers introduces much-anticipated film unit that will make and distribute art-house movies; unit, to be called Warner Independent Films, will be led by Mark Gill (S)
data.text:
Warner Brothers today introduced a much-anticipated film unit that will make and distribute art-house movies. The unit will be led by Mark Gill, a former Miramax Films executive.

The new unit, to be called Warner Independent Films, will give Warner a full line of films to make and distribute -- from low-budget films that play festivals to big-budget, event movies like the recent series of ''Matrix'' films.

''We have long felt that in order to truly be a full-service studio, we need to produce, distribute and market all genres of films, with all size budgets to all potential audiences,'' Warner Brothers said in a statement.

The move should also put Warner Brothers in contention for the Academy Awards. That competition, in recent years, has been an arena for art-house film labels.

Warner Brothers, a unit of AOL Time Warner, is the last of the major Hollywood studios to field such a division. Disney has Miramax, and 20th Century Fox, a unit of the Fox Entertainment Group of the News Corporation, has Fox Searchlight, to name only two.

Initially, the new Warner label will produce or acquire up to 10 films a year with budgets up to $20 million. Mr. Gill said Warner Independent would probably release its first movie next spring after he has hired a full staff.

Mr. Gill, whose title will be president of Warner Independent Films, joins the company from the independent producer Stratus Film Company, where he landed after leaving Miramax in 2002.
